citation.article-title: Phylogenetic Analysis of Five Strains of Gram-Negative, Obligately Anaerobic, Sulfur-Reducing Bacteria and Description of Desulfuromusa gen. nov., Including Desulfuromusa kysingii sp. nov., Desulfuromusa bakii sp. nov., and Desulfuromusa succinoxidans sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Desulfuromusa succinoxidans sp. nov.

Desulfuromusa succinoxidans (suc.cin.ox'i.dans. L. n. succinum, amber; M.L. n. acidum succinicum, succinic acid [derived from amber]; M.L. v. oxido, make acid, oxidize; M.L. part.adj. succinoxidans, oxidizing succinate)
Cells are 0.8 to 1.0 μm wide and 4 to 6 μm long when they are grown on elemental sulfur as the electron acceptor.
Nitrate, dimethyl sulfoxide, and Fe(III)-citrate are not utilized.
Cells grow with aspartate or maleate without additional electron acceptors, but growth is considerably slower than growth in the presence of elemental sulfur.
Acetate, pyruvate, lactate, propionate, oxalacetate, succinate, maleate, alanine, glutamate, aspartate, and yeast extract are used as electron donors.
Citrate is not utilized as an electron donor.
Strains can be cultivated in defined medium without addition of complex nutrients like yeast extract or peptone.
Cells grow in the presence of NaCl and MgCl, concentrations of 114 and 3.3 mM, respectively.
The optimum pH for growth is between 6.5 and 7.9; minimum and maximum pH values for growth are 5.8 and 8.25, respectively.
The minimum temperature for growth is 4°C; the maximum temperature is 35°C; and the optimum temperature is around 32°C.
The type strain of Desulfuromusa succinoxidans is strain Gylac (= DSM 8270); the G+C content of its DNA is 46 mol%.
Desulfuromusa succinoxidans GylacT was isolated from an anoxic mud sample collected at a depth of about 2,000 m from the Guayamas Basin (Gulf of California)
